routes.documentation: Lists all of the available IoT Hub REST API operations.
Get all the IoT hubs in a subscription

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The body contains a JSON-serialized array of the metadata from all the IoT hubs in the subscription.

routes.documentation: Check if an IoT hub name is available

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The body contains a JSON-serialized response that specifies whether the IoT hub name is available. If the name is not available, the body contains the reason.

routes.documentation: Get the number of iot hubs in the subscription
Get all the IoT hubs in a resource group

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The body contains a JSON-serialized array of the metadata from all the IoT hubs in the resource group.

routes.documentation: Manually initiate a failover for the IoT Hub to its secondary region

responses.label: Long running manual failover operation for the IoT hub completed

routes.documentation: Test all routes
Test the new route
Get the health for routing endpoints
Delete an IoT hub

responses.label: This is returned as a response to the status polling request for the delete operation. The body contains the resource representation that indicates a transitional provisioning state.

The Iot Hub resource provider always returns a 202 Accepted status code with valid Location and Retry-After headers. The resource provider also sets the Azure-AsyncOperation header with a URL that points to the operation resource for this operation. Subsequent GET attempts on the resource after a DELETE operation return a resource representation that indicates a transitional provisioning state (such as Terminating). To retrieve the status of the operation, a client can either poll the URL returned in the Location header after the Retry-After interval, get the IoT Hub service status directly, or query the operation resource.

Once the long running delete operation completes successfully, a 204 No Content status code is returned when the status polling request finds the Iot hub metadata in the service and the status of the delete operation is set to a completed state.
After the long running delete operation completes successfully, a 404 Not Found is returned when the status polling request no longer finds the Iot hub metadata in the service.

routes.documentation: Get the non-security related metadata of an IoT hub

responses.label: The body contains all the non-security properties of the IoT hub. Security-related properties are set to null.

routes.documentation: Update an existing IoT Hubs tags.
Create or update the metadata of an IoT hub.

responses.label: This is returned as a response to the status polling request for the create or update operation. The body contains the resource representation that indicates a transitional provisioning state.

This is a long running operation. The operation returns a 201 if the validation is complete. The response includes an Azure-AsyncOperation header that contains a status URL. Clients are expected to poll the status URL for the status of the operation. If successful, the operation returns HTTP status code of 201 (OK).

routes.documentation: Get a shared access policy by name from an IoT hub. For more information, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/iot-hub/iot-hub-devguide-security

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The body contains a JSON-serialized shared access policy, including keys, that you can use to access one or more IoT hub endpoints.

routes.documentation: Get the statistics from an IoT hub

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The body contains JSON-serialized statistics from the identity registry in the IoT hub.

routes.documentation: Get the certificate list.

responses.label: The body contains all the certificate list.

routes.documentation: Delete an X509 certificate.
Get the certificate.
Upload the certificate to the IoT hub.

responses.label: If certificate already exist and update was successful, the operation returns HTTP status code of 201 (OK).
If certificate didn't exist creation was successful, the operation returns HTTP status code of 201 (OK).

routes.documentation: Generate verification code for proof of possession flow.
Verify certificate's private key possession.
Get a list of the consumer groups in the Event Hub-compatible device-to-cloud endpoint in an IoT hub

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The body contains a JSON-serialized list of the consumer groups in the Event Hub-compatible endpoint in this IoT hub

routes.documentation: Delete a consumer group from an Event Hub-compatible endpoint in an IoT hub
Get a consumer group from the Event Hub-compatible device-to-cloud endpoint for an IoT hub

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The body contains a JSON-serialized consumer group.

routes.documentation: Add a consumer group to an Event Hub-compatible endpoint in an IoT hub

Exports all the device identities in the IoT hub identity registry to an Azure Storage blob container. For more information, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/iot-hub/iot-hub-devguide-identity-registry#import-and-export-device-identities

Import, update, or delete device identities in the IoT hub identity registry from a blob. For more information, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/iot-hub/iot-hub-devguide-identity-registry#import-and-export-device-identities
Get a list of all the jobs in an IoT hub. For more information, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/iot-hub/iot-hub-devguide-identity-registry

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The response contains a JSON-serialized array of all the jobs in the IoT hub.

routes.documentation: Get the details of a job from an IoT hub. For more information, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/iot-hub/iot-hub-devguide-identity-registry

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The response contains a JSON-serialized description of the job in the IoT hub.

routes.documentation: Get the security metadata for an IoT hub. For more information, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/iot-hub/iot-hub-devguide-security

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The body contains a JSON-serialized array of shared access policies, including keys, that you can use to access the IoT hub endpoints.

routes.documentation: Get the quota metrics for an IoT hub

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The response contains a JSON-serialized array of the quota metrics for the IoT hub.

routes.documentation: Get the list of valid SKUs for an IoT hub

responses.label: This is a synchronous operation. The body contains a JSON-serialized array of the valid SKUs for this IoT hub.
